name: Pluto

sections.content: Pluto is the Greco-Roman god of the underworld and wealth, ruling over the realm of the dead with his queen Persephone.
sections.title: Description

description: Pluto (Greek: Plouton, meaning 'the wealthy one') is the Greco-Roman god of the underworld, the dead, and subterranean wealth. Known as Hades in earlier Greek tradition, the name Pluto emphasizes his role as bestower of the earth's riches - precious metals, gems, and the fertility that springs from the soil. As ruler of the underworld, he presides over the realm where all mortal souls eventually journey. Unlike the malevolent death gods of other cultures, Pluto is portrayed as stern but just, maintaining the cosmic order between the living and the dead. His abduction of Persephone and their subsequent marriage forms one of mythology's most significant narratives, explaining the cycle of seasons.

hoverInfo.quick: God of the underworld and wealth, ruler of the dead...

listDisplay.expandedContent: Pluto is the Greco-Roman god of the underworld and wealth.
listDisplay.secondary: Ruler of the dead and bestower of earthly riches...

summary: Pluto is the Greco-Roman god of the underworld, the dead, and subterranean wealth, ruling alongside his queen Persephone.

origins.title: Origins
origins.content: Pluto was born as the eldest son of the Titans Cronus and Rhea. Along with his siblings, he was swallowed by his father who feared a prophecy that his children would overthrow him. After Zeus freed his siblings from Cronus's stomach, the three brothers - Zeus, Poseidon, and Pluto (Hades) - drew lots to divide the cosmos. Zeus received the sky, Poseidon the seas, and Pluto the underworld. The name 'Pluto' (Plouton) meaning 'the wealthy one' became the preferred epithet in later Greek and Roman religion, emphasizing his role as lord of earth's treasures rather than the fearsome ruler of the dead.

mythology.title: Mythology
mythology.content: The most famous myth involving Pluto is his abduction of Persephone, daughter of Demeter. Seeing the beautiful maiden gathering flowers, Pluto rose from the earth in his golden chariot and carried her to his underground kingdom. Demeter's grief caused all plants to wither, threatening humanity with famine. Zeus intervened, but because Persephone had eaten pomegranate seeds in the underworld, she was bound to return there for part of each year. This myth explains the seasons: spring and summer occur when Persephone is with her mother, while autumn and winter mark her return to Pluto's realm. Unlike other Olympians, Pluto appears in few myths, as his realm was separate from the world of the living.

attributes.title: Attributes
attributes.content: Pluto possesses the Helm of Darkness (or Cap of Invisibility), forged by the Cyclopes during the Titanomachy, which renders him invisible. He carries a bident, a two-pronged fork symbolizing his rule over the underworld just as Zeus's thunderbolt and Poseidon's trident represent their domains. The cornucopia (horn of plenty) emphasizes his aspect as giver of agricultural and mineral wealth. Cerberus, the three-headed hound, guards the gates of his realm. Pluto is described as dark-bearded, stern, and majestic, seated on an ebony throne. He rarely leaves his kingdom, making him virtually unknown to mortals and inspiring both dread and reverence.

culturalRole.title: Cultural Role
culturalRole.content: In Greek religion, Pluto was worshipped with averted faces and sacrifices of black animals, as looking directly at death was considered dangerous. The Romans syncretized him with their native deity Dis Pater and the Etruscan Aita. Unlike the malevolent death figures in other mythologies, Pluto represented the natural order - impartial, inevitable, but not evil. His temples were few, as Greeks preferred not to invoke death, but his role in the Eleusinian Mysteries was central, representing the soul's journey and the promise of a blessed afterlife. The philosophical schools saw Pluto as representing the transformation of death into new life, with wealth emerging from the decomposition beneath the soil.
